changeable_areas_annotations.file_path: Name of the dataset to be loaded

goal: Import necessary packages and load data for visualization

changeable_areas_annotations.x: The column to be plotted on the horizontal axis
changeable_areas_annotations.y: The column to be plotted on the vertical axis
changeable_areas_annotations.hue: The column to be used for categorizing variables (optional)
changeable_areas_annotations.palette: The color palette for the plot

lines: figure = sns.boxplot(x=@@x@@, y=@@y@@, hue=@@hue@@, palette=@@palette@@, data=dataset)

goal: Create a box plot that shows...

changeable_areas_annotations.measurement: The column used to create separate subplots (columns)
changeable_areas_annotations.share_y_axis: Whether subplots should share the same vertical scale

changeable_areas_annotations.plot_type: The Seaborn plotting function to apply to the grid
changeable_areas_annotations.x: The column for the horizontal axis within each facet
changeable_areas_annotations.y: The column for the vertical axis within each facet
changeable_areas_annotations.palette: The color mapping for the mapped plots

goal: Map a plot type on a FacetGrid shows...

changeable_areas_annotations.title: The main title of the figure
changeable_areas_annotations.angle: Rotation angle for x-axis tick labels (in degrees)

goal: Map a plot type on a FacetGrid shows...

changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_check: The column for selecting the records that will be updated. This could be the same as the column to be updated, or a different column of the table.
changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_update: The column whose values will be replaced with the new value.
changeable_areas_annotations.condition_value: The value that the column will be checked against, which could be a numerical or string value.
changeable_areas_annotations.new_value: New value for the column that will be updated, including numerical values, strings, or expressions with other columns.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to update

goal: Update the value of a column in all records meeting a condition

plan_metadata.description: This plan is used to update the value of a field (column) in records (rows) that meet a criteria.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, replace the table with the name of the table you want to update, and decide which field will be updated and which condition will be checked. You can use the same column in both update and condition parts of the query, or you could update a field based on the values in another field for each record.
plan_metadata.usage: This plan is used when you want to update records based on some rule or criteria, such as giving extra credit to all students who have completed an activity, or marking sales above some threshold to be successful.

questions.stem: Arrange the code blocks to update the 'award_status' of songs in the 'songs' table for records where the 'artist_name' is 'Grammy Winner'.
Click on which two parts of this query would be the same if you want to replace all grades lower than 25 with zero.

changeable_areas_annotations.field_names: The fields (columns) that will be specified for the inserted records.
changeable_areas_annotations.field_values: The values for the records that will be inserted, which are provided in the same order given in field_names.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: The name of the table to be updated.

goal: Insert a new record (row) into the specified table with values for specified columns

plan_metadata.description: This is a plan to add new records (rows) into a table.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, replace the name of the table, specify which fields will exist in the row you will insert, and then provide the values for those fields.
plan_metadata.usage: This plan is used when you want to add more data to a table in your database.

questions.stem: Arrange the code blocks to insert a new record into the 'users' table with the specified field names and values.

You are tasked with adding a new record into the 'movies' table in a database using SQL. Which of the following SQL statements correctly adds a movie titled 'Inception', released on '2010-07-16', with the genre 'Sci-Fi'?
questions.correct: INSERT INTO movies (title, release_date, genre) VALUES ('Inception', '2010-07-16', 'Sci-Fi');
distractors: INSERT INTO users (title, release_date, genre) VALUES ('Inception', '2010-07-16', 'Sci-Fi');
feedback: Incorrect. This statement attempts to insert into the 'users' table, which is not where movie data belongs.
Incorrect. This statement uses the wrong field names for the 'movies' table. It should be (title, release_date, genre).
Incorrect. This statement attempts to insert into the 'users' table, which is not where movie data belongs.

goal: Alter the existing table to remove an unnecessary column

plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, follow these steps...

distractors: ALTER TABLE Books REMOVE COLUMN Edition;
feedback: The SQL command to remove a column is 'DROP COLUMN', not 'REMOVE COLUMN'.
The syntax for deleting a column is incorrect. You need to use 'ALTER TABLE ... DROP COLUMN'.
The correct SQL syntax is 'ALTER TABLE ... DROP COLUMN', not 'DELETE COLUMN'.
questions.stem: You are working with a database for a library management system. The table 'Books' contains a column 'Edition' that is no longer needed. How would you remove this column from the 'Books' table?
questions.correct: ALTER TABLE Books DROP COLUMN Edition;

changeable_areas_annotations.aggregation_func: A function that will process the values in each group and return a single summary value.
changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_process: The column(s) over which the aggregation function will be run.
changeable_areas_annotations.optional_column_to_group: Optional value - omit if you want to calculate statistics over all records. The column name that records will be grouped by. When you run this query, all the records with the same value in this column will be grouped together, and the aggregation function will be executed separately for each group.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to be examined.

goal: Calculate aggregated summary statistics for the whole table, or for subsets of the table

plan_metadata.description: This is a plan to view records summarized by some attribute. By summarize, we mean using some kind of aggregation function: such as taking the mean, maximum, minimum, or sum of the values. You can calculate this summary in subsets of the data (by using the GROUP BY part of the query), or you can calculate the summary values across all records.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, replace the name of the table with your table, decide which function you want to use and which column(s) you want to summarize or see. If you want to calculate summary values over subsets, keep the GROUP BY line in the query and replace the column with a field. A separate group will be shown for each value of that field. For example, if you select AVG(quiz_grade) and if you group by letter_grade, you can see what was the average quiz grade for students who got an A, for students who got a B, etc.
plan_metadata.usage: This plan is used when you want to get insights about your data by using statistical aggregation functions.

questions.stem: Arrange the following SQL query blocks to calculate the maximum value of 'column_2' for each genre in the 'movies' table.
In the context of a movie database, using the plan 'Summarize Records', the SQL query 'SELECT genre, AVG(rating) FROM movies GROUP BY genre;' correctly calculates the average rating for each genre.
questions.label: True
questions.feedback: This query correctly uses the 'AVG' aggregation function on the 'rating' column and groups the results by 'genre', which is a valid approach to obtain the average rating for each genre.

questions.stem: Using the 'Summarize Records' plan, the following query will correctly calculate the average rating of movies grouped by genre: SELECT genre, AVG(rating) FROM movies GROUP BY genre;
questions.label: True
questions.feedback: Make sure to check if the aggregation function and the column names used in the query match the plan's template structure.

changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_sort_by: The column that will be used for sorting the records.
changeable_areas_annotations.order_direction: The direction for the table to be sorted (ascending or descending)
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to be examined.

goal: View records sorted in a given order

plan_metadata.description: This plan is used to see records (rows) sorted by some field (column), without actually modifying the table. The sorting will only apply to the output you see. It will not be ordered if you try to see it with a regular SELECT query.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, complete the fields of the regular SELECT query as you saw in 'View Records', and then provide which field (column) to sort the records by, along with whether you want it ascending or descending.
plan_metadata.usage: This plan may be used to see who are the top performers in a class, or which products in a database have the cheapest prices.

questions.stem: In a music database, to view all songs sorted by their release date in descending order, the following query is used: SELECT * FROM songs ORDER BY release_date DESC;
questions.label: True
questions.feedback: Remember that DESC is used to sort results in descending order, which means from newest to oldest.

questions.stem: You are working with a music database and need to retrieve a list of songs sorted by their release date in descending order. Which SQL query would you use?
questions.correct: SELECT * FROM songs ORDER BY release_date DESC;
distractors: SELECT * FROM songs ORDER BY release_date ASC;
SELECT * FROM songs ORDER BY column_name DESC;
SELECT * FROM table_name ORDER BY release_date DESC;
feedback: This option sorts the songs in ascending order, showing the oldest songs first. You need to sort them in descending order.
This option uses 'column_name' instead of 'release_date'. Make sure to use the correct column to sort by.
This option uses 'table_name' instead of 'songs'. Ensure you are querying from the correct table.

changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_process: The column(s) over which the processing function will be run.
changeable_areas_annotations.processing_function: A function that will process the values and return a processed value for each record.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to be examined.

goal: Calculate aggregated summary statistics for the whole table, or for subsets of the table

plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, follow these steps...

questions.stem: You are given a database table named 'students' with columns 'name', 'age', and 'grade'. You need to calculate the average grade of all students. Which SQL query correctly uses the 'View Processed Records' plan to achieve this?
feedback: The LENGTH function is used to calculate the length of a string, not to find an average.
This query calculates the average age, not the grade.
This query sums up the grades instead of calculating the average.

questions.stem: Suppose you have a database table named 'sales_data' which contains information about sales transactions. You want to calculate the sum of all sales figures in a column named 'total_sales'. Fill in the blank in the SQL query template to achieve this.

changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_check: The column for selecting the records that will be updated. This could be the same as the column to be updated, or a different column of the table.
changeable_areas_annotations.column_to_update: The column whose values will be replaced with the new value.
changeable_areas_annotations.condition_value: The value that the column will be checked against, which could be a numerical or string value.
changeable_areas_annotations.new_value: New value for the column that will be updated, including numerical values, strings, or expressions with other columns.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to update

goal: Update the value of a column in all records meeting a condition

plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, follow these steps...

questions.stem: You need to update the email addresses of users in a database if their current email address matches a certain condition. Click on the field that you would need to change to check if the email column in the given table is 'test@email.com'.

You need to update the verification status of users in a database if their current email address matches a certain condition. Click on the field that you would need to change to set the verified_status column to True.

In a database of customer records, you want to update all records with an email of 'test@email.com' by setting their 'column_name' to 'a_new_value'. The query 'UPDATE table_name SET column_name = 'a_new_value' WHERE column1 = 'test@email.com';' will achieve this goal.
questions.label: True
questions.feedback: Ensure that the column being checked is correctly specified and that the new value is being set to the desired column.

changeable_areas_annotations.column_or_columns: Names of the fields (columns) to be viewed as a list separated by commas, or just a single column name, or an asterisk for all columns.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to be examined.

goal: Select and view columns from the specified table

plan_metadata.description: The most fundamental query we will learn about is viewing records from the table using SELECT. This query will return a list of records (rows). For each record, you can see values for the fields (columns) that you specify in the query.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, replace the table with the table you want to get records (rows) from, and specify the fields (columns) you want to look for.
plan_metadata.usage: Use this plan when you want to **view** some values in the database without modifying the table.

questions.stem: Complete the query to show the values of student_id for all records in the table student_grades.
In the context of a database system where you want to view student records, the following SQL statement correctly selects all columns from the student_grades table: SELECT * FROM student_grades;
questions.label: True
questions.feedback: The SQL statement is correct. Using '*' in the SELECT clause retrieves all columns from the specified table, which in this case is 'student_grades'.

changeable_areas_annotations.column_or_columns: Names of the fields (columns) to be viewed as a list separated by commas, or just a single column name, or an asterisk for all columns.
changeable_areas_annotations.table: Name of the table to be examined.

goal: Select and view columns from the specified table

plan_metadata.description: The most fundamental query we will learn about is viewing records from the table using SELECT. This query will return a list of records (rows). For each record, you can see values for the fields (columns) that you specify in the query.
plan_metadata.instruction: To use this plan, replace the table with the table you want to get records (rows) from, and specify the fields (columns) you want to look for.
plan_metadata.usage: Use this plan when you want to **view** some values in the database without modifying the table.

questions.stem: Complete the query to show the values of student_id for all records in the table student_grades.
In the context of a database system where you want to view student records, the following SQL statement correctly selects all columns from the student_grades table: SELECT * FROM student_grades;
